tit.e: Manyo-gana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyo-shu or Collection of Myriad Leaves)
Manyo-gana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyo-shu or Collection of Myriad Leaves)
Manyo-gana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves])
tit.cmt: 用語補足を変えました。

sen.j: 万葉仮名（まんようがな）とは仮名 (文字)の一種で、主として上代に日本語を表記するために漢字の音を借用して用いられた文字のことである。
sen.e: Manyo-gana is a kind of kana (the Japanese syllabaries), and it mainly refers to the letters from which Japanese people borrowed the Chinese-derived pronunciation in order to express Japanese in ancient times.

Manyo-gana is a kind of kana (the Japanese syllabaries), and it mainly refers to the letters from which Japanese people borrowed Chinese-derived pronunciation in order to express Japanese in ancient times.

Manyo-gana is a kind of kana (the Japanese syllabaries), and it mainly refers to the letters from which Japanese people borrowed Chinese-derived pronunciation in order to express Japanese in ancient times.

sen.j: 『萬葉集』（万葉集）での表記に代表されるため、この名前がある。
sen.e: These letters are represented by the writing in "Manyoshu," therefore they are called in this way.
These letters are represented by the writing in "Manyoshu," and therefore they are called in this way.
These letters are represented by the writing in "Manyoshu," and therefore they are called in this way.

sen.j: 真仮名（まがな）、借字ともいう。
sen.e: They are also called Magana or Shakuji.
They are also called Magana or Shakuji.
They are also called Magana or Shakuji.

sen.j: 仮借の一種。
sen.e: They are a kind of phonetic loan characters.
They are a kind of phonetic loan characters.
They are a kind of phonetic loan characters.

sen.j: 楷書体ないし行書体で表現された漢字の一字一字を、その義（漢字本来の意味）に拘わらずに日本語の一音節の表記のために用いるというのが万葉仮名の最大の特徴である。
sen.e: The biggest characteristic of Manyo-gana is that regardless of the meanings of the Chinese characters, the letter was used to represent each syllable of Japanese which was expressed with Chinese characters in a square or a cursive style.

The most prominent characteristic of Manyo-gana is that, regardless of the meanings of the Chinese characters, one letter was used to represent each syllable of Japanese which was expressed with Chinese characters in a square or a cursive style.

The most prominent characteristic of Manyo-gana is that, regardless of the meanings of the Chinese characters, one letter was used to represent each syllable of Japanese which was expressed with Chinese characters in a square or a cursive style.

sen.j: 万葉集を一種の頂点とするのでこう呼ばれる。
sen.e: They were used most in Manyoshu, so called like this.
They were used most in Manyoshu, and therefore called like this.
They were used most in Manyoshu, and therefore called like this.

sen.j: 『古事記』や『日本書紀』の歌謡や訓注などの表記も万葉集と同様である。
sen.e: The way of writing ballads and kunchu (notes on kun (Japanese readings)) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) is the same as that in Manyoshu.
The way of writing ballads and kunchu (notes on kun (Japanese readings)) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) is the same as that in Manyoshu.
The way of writing ballads and kunchu (notes on kun [Japanese readings]) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) is the same as that in Manyoshu.

sen.j: 『古事記』には呉音が、『日本書紀』α群には漢音が反映されている。
sen.e: The Wu reading was reflected in "Kojiki," while the Han reading was reflected in the a group of "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: αは半角で入力できないため、暫定的に半角の「a」を用いました。
sen.e: The Wu reading was reflected in "Kojiki," while the Han reading was reflected in the a group of "Nihonshoki."
The Wu reading was reflected in "Kojiki," while the Han reading was reflected in the α group of "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: 江戸時代の和学者・春登上人は『万葉用字格』（1818年）の中で、万葉仮名を五十音順に整理し〈正音・略音・正訓・義訓・略訓・約訓・借訓・戯書〉に分類した。
sen.e: The venerable Shunto, who was a scholar of the Japanese classics in the Edo period, classified Manyo-gana in the order of the Japanese syllabary (seion, ryakuon, seikun (the correct Japanese reading), gikun, ryakkun, yakukun, shakkun (borrowed meaning), and gisho) in "Manyo Yojikaku" (1818).
sen.cmt: 約訓の正しい読み方不明です正音・略音・義訓・略訓・約訓・戯書の英訳不明のため、ローマ字表記のみです。
sen.e: The venerable Shunto, who was a scholar of the Japanese classics in the Edo period, classified Manyo-gana in the order of the Japanese syllabary (seion, ryakuon, seikun (the correct Japanese reading), gikun, ryakkun, yakukun, shakkun (borrowed meaning), and gisho) in "Manyo Yojikaku" (1818).

Shunto Shonin (the venerable Shunto), who was a scholar of the Japanese classics in the Edo period, classified Manyo-gana in the order of the Japanese syllabary into seion (literally, Chinese-derived character reading in normal manner), ryakuon (literally, Chinese-derived character reading in short manner), seikun (literally, native Japanese reading in normal manner), gikun (literally, native Japanese reading by meaning of Chinese character), ryakkun (literally, native Japanese reading in short manner), yakukun (literally, native Japanese reading in brief manner), shakkun (literally, native Japanese reading in borrowed manner), and gisho (literally, playful and technical reading) in "Manyo Yojikaku" (1818).
sen.cmt: 表記を変え、用語補足しました。

sen.j: 万葉仮名の字体をその字源によって分類すると記紀・万葉を通じてその数は973に達する。
sen.e: The number of Manyogana used in the Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Manyoshu reaches 973, when they are classified in accordance with the origins of the characters.
The number of Manyogana used in the Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Manyoshu reaches 973 when they are classified in accordance with the origins of the characters.
The number of Manyo-gana used in the Kojiki, Nihonshoki, and Manyoshu reaches 973 when they are classified in accordance with the origins of the characters.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 万葉集や日本書紀に現れた表記のあり方は整っており、万葉仮名がいつ生まれたのかということは疑問であった。
sen.e: The way of writing in Manyoshu and Nihonshoki was organized, so it has been unknown when Manyo-gana was generated.
The way of writing in Manyoshu and Nihonshoki was organized, and therefore it is not known when Manyo-gana was generated.
The way of writing in Manyoshu and Nihonshoki was organized, and therefore it is not known when Manyo-gana was generated.

sen.j: 正倉院に遺された文書や木簡資料の発掘などにより万葉仮名は7世紀ごろには成立したとされている。
sen.e: It is considered that Manyo-gana was completed around the 7th century from the documents left in the Shosoin Treasure House and excavation of materials written on narrow strips of wood.
It is considered that Manyo-gana was completed around the 7th century, from documents left in the Shosoin Treasure House and excavation of materials written on narrow strips of wood.
It is considered that Manyo-gana was completed around the seventh century, from documents left in the Shosoin Treasure House and excavation of materials written on narrow strips of wood.
sen.cmt: スペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 実際の使用が確かめられる資料のうち最古のものは、大阪市中央区の難波宮（なにわのみや）跡において発掘された652年以前の木簡である。
sen.e: The oldest material among the ones actually used is the wooden strip, which was made before 652 and excavated in Naniwanomiya, Chuo Ward, Osaka City.
The oldest material among the ones actually used is the wooden strip, which was made before 652 and excavated in Naniwanomiya, Chuo Ward, Osaka City.
The oldest material among the ones actually used is the wooden strip, which was made before 652 and excavated in Naniwanomiya, Chuo Ward, Osaka City.

sen.j: 「皮留久佐乃皮斯米之刀斯（はるくさのはじめのとし）」と和歌の冒頭と見られる11文字が記されている。
sen.e: 11 letters which seem to have been the opening line of waka poetry, '皮留久佐乃皮斯米之刀斯' (ha ru ku sa no ha ji me no to shi) were written on it.
11 letters which seem to have been the opening line of waka poetry, '皮留久佐乃皮斯米之刀斯' (ha ru ku sa no ha ji me no to shi) were written on it.
11 characters which seem to have been the opening line of waka poetry, 'ha ru ku sa no ha ji me no to shi' (皮留久佐乃皮斯米之刀斯, literally, the first year of spring plants) were written on it.

sen.j: しかしながらさらに古い5世紀の稲荷山古墳から発見された金錯銘鉄剣には「獲加多支鹵（わかたける）大王」という21代雄略天皇に推定される名が刻まれている。
sen.e: However, iron sword with gold inscription, which was found from Inariyama-kofun Tumulus made in the 5th century, is older, and it has a possible name of the 21st Emperor Yuryaku, '獲加多支鹵' (wa ka ta ke ru), on it.

However, an iron sword with gold inscription, which was found from Inariyama-kofun Tumulus made in the 5th century, is older, and it has a possible name of the 21st Emperor Yuryaku, '獲加多支鹵' (wa ka ta ke ru), on it.

However, an iron sword with gold inscription, which was found from Inariyama-kofun Tumulus made in the fifth century, is older, and it has a possible name of the 21st Emperor Yuryaku, 'wa ka ta ke ru daio' (獲加多支鹵大王, the King Wakatakeru), on it.

sen.j: これも漢字の音を借りた万葉仮名の一種とされる。
sen.e: It is considered that this was a kind of Manyo-gana, which borrowed a sound of Chinese characters.
It is considered that this was a kind of Manyo-gana, which borrowed sounds of Chinese characters.
It is considered that this was a kind of Manyo-gana, which borrowed sounds of Chinese characters.

sen.j: 漢字の音を借りて固有語を表記する方法は5世紀には確立していた事になる。
sen.e: This means that the way of writing proper nouns borrowing the sound of Chinese characters had been established at least in the 5th century.
This means that the way of writing proper nouns borrowing the sound of Chinese characters had been established at least by the 5th century.
This means that the way of writing proper nouns borrowing the sound of Chinese characters had been established at least by the fifth century.
sen.cmt: スペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 平安時代には万葉仮名をもとにして平仮名と片仮名が作られた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, hiragana (the Japanese cursive syllabary) and katakana syllabary were made on the basis of Manyo-gana.
In the Heian period, hiragana (the Japanese cursive syllabary) and katakana syllabary were made on the basis of Manyo-gana.
In the Heian period, hiragana (the Japanese cursive syllabary) and katakana (syllable based writing system of the Japanese language) were made on the basis of Manyo-gana.

sen.j: 1. 字音を借りたもの（借音仮名）
sen.e: 1. The letters borrowed from the pronunciation of Chinese characters (shakuon kana (sound borrowing syllabary))
1. The letters borrowed from the pronunciation of Chinese characters (shakuon kana (sound borrowing syllabary))
1. The letters borrowed from the pronunciation of Chinese characters (shakuon kana [sound borrowing syllabary])

sen.j: 一字が一音を表わすもの
sen.e: Each letter represents one mora.
Each letter represents one mora.
Characters that represent one mora in each

sen.j: 全用 以（い）、呂（ろ）、波（は）、…
sen.e: Complete, 以 (i), 呂 (ro), 波 (ha),...
Complete, 以 (i), 呂 (ro), 波 (ha),...
Complete: I (以, い), Ro (呂, ろ), Ha (波, は),...

sen.j: 略用 安（あ）、楽（ら）、天（て）、…
sen.e: Partial, 安 (a), 楽 (ra), 天 (te), …
Partial, 安 (a), 楽 (ra), 天 (te), …
Partial: A (安, あ), Ra (楽, ら), Te (天, て),...

sen.j: 一字が二音を表わすもの
sen.e: Each letter represents two morae.
Each letter represents two morae.
Characters that represent two morae in each

sen.j: 信（しな）、覧（らむ）、相（さが）、…
sen.e: 信 (shina), 覧(ramu), 相 (saga), …
信 (shina), 覧(ramu), 相 (saga), …
Shi-na (信, しな), Ra-mu (覧, らむ), Sa-ga (相, さが),...

sen.j: 2. 字訓を借りたもの（借訓仮名）
sen.e: 2. The letters borrowed from the meaning of Chinese characters (shakkun kana (borrowed meaning syllabary))
2. The letters borrowed from the meaning of Chinese characters (shakkun kana (borrowed meaning syllabary))
2. The letters borrowed from the meaning of Chinese characters (shakkun kana [borrowed meaning syllabary])

sen.j: 一字が一音を表わすもの
sen.e: Each letter represent one mora.
Each letter represent one mora.

sen.j: 全用 女（め）、毛（け）、蚊（か）、…
sen.e: Complete, 女 (me), 毛 (ke), 蚊 (ka), …
Complete, 女 (me), 毛 (ke), 蚊 (ka), …
Complete: Me (女, め), Ke (毛, け), Ka (蚊, か),...

sen.e: Partial, 石 (shi), 跡 (to), 市 (chi), …

sen.j: 一字が二音を表わすもの
sen.e: Each letter represents two morae.

sen.j: 蟻（あり）、巻（まく）、鴨（かも）、…
sen.e: 蟻 (ari), 巻 (maku), 鴨 (kamo), …
蟻 (ari), 巻 (maku), 鴨 (kamo), …
A-ri (蟻, あり), Ma-ku (巻, まく), Ka-mo (鴨, かも),...

sen.j: 一字が三音を表わすもの
sen.e: Each letter represents three morae.

sen.j: 慍 (いかり), 下 (おろし), 炊 (かしき)
sen.e: 慍 (ikari), 下 (oroshi), 炊 (kashiki)
慍 (ikari), 下 (oroshi), 炊 (kashiki)
I-ka-ri (慍, いかり), O-ro-shi (下, おろし), Ka-shi-ki (炊, かしき)

sen.j: 二字が一音を表わすもの
sen.e: Two letters represent one mora.

Characters that represent one mora in two

sen.j: 嗚呼（あ）、五十（い）、可愛（え）、二二 (し), 蜂音 (ぶ)
sen.e: 嗚呼 (a), 五十 (i), 可愛 (e), 二二 (shi), 蜂音 (bu)

sen.e: Three letters represent two morae.

sen.j: 八十一 (くく), 神楽声 (ささ)
sen.e: 八十一 (kuku), 神楽声 (sasa)
八十一 (kuku), 神楽声 (sasa)
